settings.text: You find this VHS tape on the ground. What a nice welcome!

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: You're back!

lines.speaker: Box
lines.text: "hello"

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: *beeps*

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: It doesn't take long when you're traveling at the speed of light!

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Your entire journey is virtually instant.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: that sounds nauseating!

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: well anyway, we picked you up some grub in Perth like you asked, Karen!

lines.speaker: notice
lines.text: You give Karen the... food.

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: Oh, wow, food!... I love food!

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: This kind of junk is my favorite!

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: so where do we go from here? across the ocean this time, or back across Australia again?

lines.speaker: Orb
lines.text: PROOF OF TCP HANDSHAKE WITH SERVER MUST BE PROVIDED BEFORE CONTENT CAN BE TRANSMITTED OVER HTTP.

lines.speaker: Orb
lines.text: NO OVERSEAS TRAVEL IS PERMITTED UNTIL SUCH PROOF IS DISPLAYED.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: well, I guess we *are* going overseas, but not yet.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: what do we need, Guide?

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Good news, travelers! You're ready for the next stage of the HTTP process. It's time to Sync! That! Server!!

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: is this a game show?

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Get ready for the ride of your life on the TCP! What's behind door number one?

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: okay, so what's TCP?

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: There's no need to play dumb, let's answer this question together!

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: hey, is this where we talk about protocols, like we mentioned earlier?

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: I have a feeling it is

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: And your feeling is correct!

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: The vast majority of all packets sent through a server are Internet Protocol packets, but we're about to talk about TCP, which is built on top of IP.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Let's take a step back and look at the layers of a network, for context.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Here's the simplest version of how this layering works.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: so all the physical cabling and routers are at the bottom?

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Yes! That's the **link layer**, where everything is just ones and zeroes, cables and routers, electricity and light.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Every successive layer makes use of what's on the layer below it.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Though it's worth noting this is purely a conceptual diagram – the upper layers nest within each other like your human matroshka dolls.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: ...*human* matroshka dolls?

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: The next layer up is the **network layer**, which is (for our purposes) just uses the Internet Protocol, which is the basic shell of any packet.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Which you've talked about already!

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: so the **transport layer** is above that, and can be either UDP or TCP, which are both protocols?

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: sorry, what's a protocol again?

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Excellent question! A **protocol** is just an agreed-upon set of rules for communicating data.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: A router that can't understand the Internet Protocol could hardly be called a router at all!

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: We have a lot of protocols here in the packetsphere, because there are all kinds of different types of data and ways they ought to be sent.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: alright, I'm sold. give me the business about these transport layer protocols.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: These two protocols are UDP and TCP.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: UDP stands for **User Datagram Protocol**, which is simple and fast, but can't deal with packet problems if they arise.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: TCP stands for **Transmission Control Protocol**. It's a little slower, but it can make sure all the necessary fragments of a message are reassembled correctly.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: some very inspired names here

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: yeah – so which one do we use?

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: That depends!

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Things that depend on speed that don't mind a lost packet or two are fine on UDP. Real-time video streaming is a good example.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Or things where the likelihood of packet reassembly is so low that speed matters more.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Remember when you went through the DNS process to get your destination IP address?

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: yeah, that was like a couple minutes ago

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: More likely a few nanoseconds.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: But it was over UDP!

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: you keep saying things are "over" some protocol. is the IP packet, like... sending more packets?

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Ah, no! This is where the packet becomes the human matroshka doll.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: The information necessary to send something via UDP is located *inside* the data portion of the IP packet.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Same thing goes for TCP!

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: You can see that both of these protocols add new headers for their own uses, and then have their own data field.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: ...inside the data field of the enclosing IP packet.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Yes!

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: so, again which one are we using to actually send Zak's head?

lines.speaker: Box
lines.text: "hello"

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: TCP, without a doubt!

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Without it, your message might wind up missing parts, never to be heard from again!

lines.speaker: Box
lines.text: "hello"

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: you mentioned we needed to–

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Sync! That! Server!

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: yeah, that.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: what does that have to do with any of this TCP stuff?

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Glad you asked!

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: A UDP packet doesn't expect much more than getting sent somewhere, but TCP involves a whole process.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: The first part of that process involves synchronizing with the server you're heading to.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: You can only continue asking for content from the server over TCP once this synchronization handshake is complete.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Remember the IP address for [[redacted]] you got earlier?

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: uh, what was it... 14.1.88.255?

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Let's give them a ring!

lines.speaker: notice
lines.text: You call up [[redacted]].

lines.speaker: redacted
lines.text: This is the server for [[redacted]], located at 14.1.88.255, go ahead, over.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: I think we need to synchronize with you, because I'm trying to send my head over to Becky. Can we do that?

lines.speaker: Box
lines.text: "hello"

lines.speaker: redacted
lines.text: Affirmative, stranger. Send me a dummy TCP packet with your SYN bit to 1, over.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: okay, that was weird, but I did it

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: over?

lines.speaker: redacted
lines.text: Roger, received that, ACKnowledging it.

lines.speaker: redacted
lines.text: Sending you back a SYNchronize to check that our connection works both ways, do you copy?

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: uh, roger copy over?

lines.speaker: redacted
lines.text: (You have to ACKnowledge it, bud)

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: oh, right.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: still kind of unsettling

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: I guess that's why they typically have the routers do it, not us

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: anyways, 10-4? partner? over?

lines.speaker: redacted
lines.text: Roger that! From here until our connection is closed, ask me for whatever you need.

lines.speaker: redacted
lines.text: Every time I send you something new, I'll increase my sequence number.

lines.speaker: redacted
lines.text: Every time you receive it, you'll increase your acknowledge number, and send me an ACK back to let me know you got it.

lines.speaker: redacted
lines.text: If the numbers don't match, the router will do the work of figuring out how to reassemble the message from out-of-order packets, or ask for any missing ones.

lines.speaker: redacted
lines.text: Just make sure you send me that ACK to let me know you received it, or I'll assume it got lost and resend it!

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: so now that we're here, can we just... ask you to send Zak's head to me?

lines.speaker: redacted
lines.text: Just like that? You sure can't! You've got to word that in HTTP – that's the protocol for me.

lines.speaker: redacted
lines.text: But our connection's going to stay open until you tell me you're closing it, so just give me a holler when you've figured it out!

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: *more* protocols?

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: We'll talk about that later. For now, let's get you across the ocean!
